{{also|Der|dér|dêr|dër|děr|-der|der-}} ==English== ===Etymology 1=== ====Pronunciation==== * {{IPA|en|/dɜː/}} * {{audio|en|EN-AU ck1 der.ogg|Audio (AU)}} ====Interjection==== {{en-interj}} # {{lb|en|Australian}} {{non-gloss definition|Disdainful indication that something is [[obvious]].}} # {{lb|en|Australian}} {{non-gloss definition|Indication of [[stupidity]].}} #* {{quote-book|en|author=Gabrielle Carey and Kathy Lette|title=Puberty Blues|year=1979|page=46|passage=`Sprung!' cried Jeff Basin, the local dubbo. 'Oh, '''der''',' moaned Boardie sarcastically.}} ====Synonyms==== * {{l|en|duh}} ===Etymology 2=== Nonstandard spelling of {{m|en|there}}, reflecting any of a variety of accents with [[w:Th-stopping|''th''-stopping]]. ====Alternative forms==== * {{l|en|dere}} ====Pronunciation==== * {{a|AAVE}} {{IPA|en|/dɛː(ɹ)/}} * {{homophones|en|dare}} ====Adverb==== {{en-adv|-}} # {{nonstandard spelling of|en|there}} ====Interjection==== {{en-interjection}} # {{nonstandard spelling of|en|there}} ====Noun==== {{en-noun|-}} # {{nonstandard spelling of|en|there}} ====Pronoun==== {{en-pronoun}} # {{nonstandard spelling of|en|there}} ====Derived terms==== * {{l|en|der's}} ===Anagrams=== * {{anagrams|en|a=der|-red|DRE|EDR|ERD|RED|Red|erd|red}} [[Category:English three-letter words]] ---- ==Danish== ===Alternative forms=== * {{l|da|dær}} {{qual|obsolete}} ===Pronunciation=== * {{IPA|da|/dar/|[dɑ]|qual3=emphatic|/ˈdɛr/|[ˈdeˀɐ̯]}} * {{rhymes|da|ar}} ===Adverb=== {{da-adv}} # [[there]] (in or at that place) ===Pronoun=== {{head|da|pronoun}} # {{lb|da|relative}} [[who#English|who]], [[who#English|whom]], [[which#English|which]], [[that#English|that]] ====Usage notes==== * Only used when the relative pronoun is subject * {{l|da|som|Som}} can be used for all positions (including subject) ---- ==Dutch== ===Pronunciation=== '''stressed''' * {{IPA|nl|/dɛr/}} '''unstressed''' * {{IPA|nl|/dər/}} ===Etymology 1=== Unstressed form of {{m|nl|daar||there}}. ====Adverb==== {{nl-adv}} # [[there]] =====Synonyms===== * {{l|nl|daar}}, {{l|nl|ginder}}, {{l|nl|ginds}} =====Antonyms===== * {{l|nl|hier}}, {{l|nl|her}} ===Etymology 2=== ====Article==== {{head|nl|article}} # {{lb|nl|dated}} {{inflection of|nl|de||gen|s|f}}; of the. #: {{ux|nl|geschiedenis '''der''' Nederlandsche taal|inline=1|history of the Dutch language}} # {{lb|nl|dated}} {{inflection of|nl|de||gen|p}}; of the. #: {{ux|nl|het koninkrijk '''der''' Nederlanden|inline=1|the kingdom of the Netherlands}} # {{lb|nl|dated}} {{inflection of|nl|de||dat|s|f}}. =====Usage notes===== * Only the nominative forms are common in modern usage. Accusative and dative forms are archaic and limited to fixed expressions. Genitive forms, while still productive and regiolectal, are not part of the standardized varieties and mainly reserved for poetic and literary language. They are also found as part of surnames. * * The current pronunciation is a [[spelling pronunciation]]. Before the word became archaic, it was pronounced with a [[schwa]], {{IPAchar|/dər/}}. =====Inflection===== {{nl-decl-definite article}} ===Anagrams=== * {{l|nl|red}} [[Category:Dutch poetic terms]] ---- ==French== ===Etymology=== {{clipping|fr|dernier}} ===Pronunciation=== * {{fr-IPA}} ===Noun=== {{fr-noun|mf}} # [[last]] #: ''la '''der''' des '''ders''''' - the war that ends all wars (referring to the [[First World War]]; literally means ''the last of the lasts'' or ''the very last one'') ---- ==Galician== ===Verb=== {{gl-verb-form}} # {{inflection of|gl|dar||1|s|futr|subj}} # {{inflection of|gl|dar||3|s|futr|subj}} ---- ==German== ===Etymology=== From {{inh|de|gmh|der}}, from {{inh|de|goh|der}}, {{m|goh|ther}}, replacing the original masculine and feminine nominative forms from {{der|de|gem-pro|*sa}}, by analogy with the adjective inflection. Compare also {{cog|odt|thie}} and {{cog|ang|þē}} where the same process occurred. ===Pronunciation=== * {{IPA|de|/deːr/}} * {{IPA|de|[deːɐ̯]}} {{a|stressed}} * {{IPA|de|[dɛɐ̯]|[dɐ]}} {{a|unstressed}} * {{IPA|de|[də]}} {{a|unstressed, some dialects, feminine article only}} * {{audio|de|De-der.ogg|audio}} * {{rhymes|de|eːɐ̯}} * In colloquial speech in Germany, the /d/ can assimilate to a preceding coronal when the word is unstressed. ===Article=== {{head|de|article|definite}} # [[the]] ====Declension==== {{de-decl-definite article}} ; Old Declension: {| style="margin-left:0.5em; margin-bottom:0.5em; border: 1px solid #AAAAAA; border-collapse:collapse;" cellpadding="5" rules="all" ! colspan=5 align="center" bgcolor="#BBBBBB" | German [[definite article]]s |- ! width="65" bgcolor="#F4F4F4" | ! bgcolor="#EEEEB0" | Masculine ! bgcolor="#EEEEB0" | Feminine ! bgcolor="#EEEEB0" | Neuter ! bgcolor="#CEEEC0" | Plural |- | bgcolor="#DDDDFF" | '''[[nominative|Nominative]]''' | align="center" | {{l-self|de|der}} | align="center" | {{l-self|de|die}} | align="center" | {{l-self|de|das}}

Used with masculine singular referents. ====Declension==== {{de-decl-relative pronoun}} * By modern grammar works it is said that ''derer'' and ''deren'' can both be used without difference. * Modern grammar books mention the colloquial genitive plural form ''der''. ; Old Declension: {| style="margin-bottom:1em; margin-right:1em; border: 1px solid #AAAAAA; border-collapse:collapse;" cellpadding="4" rules="all" class="inflection-table" !colspan=5|Declension of {{m|de||der}} |- ! !bgcolor=#EFEFFF align=center |[[masculine]] !bgcolor=#EFEFFF align=center |[[feminine]] !bgcolor=#EFEFFF align=center |[[neuter]] !bgcolor=#EFEFFF align=center |[[plural]] |- !bgcolor=#EFEFFF align=left |[[nominative case|nominative]] |align=left| {{l-self|de|der}} |align=left| {{l-self|de|die}} |align=left| {{l-self|de|das}}
